messageBody:
I've always thought that in retrospect one of junit (<4)'s worse failings was creating
instances of the test classes up front in the suite. This means that
* the contructors of all tests are called before any tests are run, leading to some
interesting issues if any initialization is done there instead of in setUp,
* resources created in setUp and assigned to test class fields hang around until the end of
the test run, kept alive by the suite
* we get some very different behaviour running all tests in ant using fork=true, compared
to running all tests in the same VM

Now in junit 4 it looks like the instances of test classes are constructed on the fly. The
constructor of each test instance is called just before @Before.

So my question - is this a designed behaviour? Can I assume that junit 4 runners will have
this behaviour, allowing me to use the constructor instead of @Before, allowing fields to
be final, etc?

Does anyone have experience of constructors v @Before in junit 4?

Finally, is there scope for releasing the test class instances after each test has run? This
would give us a much smaller footprint for large test suites, without having to assign
fields to null in @After.

Thanks in anticipation

Duncan Mc^Gregor
